models package

Submodules

models.linear_system module

class LinearSystem(A: ndarray, B: ndarray | None = None, C: ndarray | None = None, D: ndarray | None = None, Bd: ndarray | None = None, Cd: ndarray | None = None, dt: float = 1)[source]

Bases: Model

Simple base class to define a linear system in state-space form. The system is assumed to be discrete-time. You can use the class method c2d obtain a discerete system from continuous time matrices if required.

Model of the system

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}x_{k+1} = A x_k + B u_k + Bd d_k\\y_k = C x_k + D u_k + Cd d_k\end{aligned}\end{align} \]
property A

State matrix

property B

Input matrix

property Bd
property C

Output matrix

property Cd
property D
static c2d(A_cont, B_cont, C_cont, D_cont, dt)[source]

Convert continuous-time state-space model to discrete-time.

Parameters:

  • A_cont (np.ndarray) – Continuous-time state matrix

  • B_cont (np.ndarray) – Continuous-time input matrix

  • C_cont (np.ndarray) – Continuous-time output matrix

  • D_cont (np.ndarray) – Continuous-time feedforward matrix

  • dt (float) – Sampling time

Returns:

Discrete-time state-space model

Return type:

LinearSystem

closed_loop_simulate(x0, L, d=None, steps=10)[source]

Simulate the LinearSystem in closed-loop with an L gain (a.k.a A-BL).

Parameters:

  • x0 (np.ndarray) – Initial state vector

  • L (np.ndarray) – Gain matrix

  • d (np.ndarray) – Disturbance signal

  • steps (int) – Number of steps to simulate

Returns x_trj:

State trajectory of shape (size_state, steps+1)

Rtype x_trj:

np.ndarray

Returns y_trj:

Output trajectory of shape (size_output, steps)

Rtype y_trj:

np.ndarray

Barebone function to plot state and output trajectories.

  • title (str) – The title of the plot.

simulate(x0, u=None, d=None, steps=10)[source]

Simulate the discrete time system for a number of steps. Input should be an array of size (size_input,steps) and disturbance should be an array of size (disturbance_size,steps) where steps is the number of steps to simulate. Note that the function will attempt to reshape your array to the given form (size_input,steps). Hence the output will not be the length you expact if you have an array with typed the wrong dimensions.

Parameters:

  • x0 (np.ndarray) – Initial state vector

  • u (np.ndarray) – Input signal

  • d (np.ndarray) – Disturbance signal

  • steps (int) – Number of steps to simulate

Return x_trj:

State trajectory of shape (size_state, steps+1)

Rtype x_trj:

np.ndarray

Return y_trj:

Output trajectory of shape (size_output, steps)

Rtype y_trj:

np.ndarray

property size_disturbance
property size_input
property size_output
property size_state
compute_lqr_controller(A, B, Q, R)[source]

Solve the discrete-time algebraic Riccati equation (DARE) for the given system.

Parameters:

  • A (np.ndarray) – The state matrix.

  • B (np.ndarray) – The input matrix.

  • Q (np.ndarray) – The state weighting matrix.

  • R (np.ndarray) – The input weighting matrix.

Returns:

Optimal gain of the LQR solution.

Return type:

np.ndarray

Returns:

symmetric postive semidefinite matrix to the discrete-time algebraic Riccati equation.

:rtype np.ndarray

models.model module

class Model(name: str | None = None)[source]

Bases: ABC

check_and_normalise_input_signals(u, d)[source]

Check and regularize the input triplet (u, d) to the model.

If d is not None and u is None, then u is set to zero with same length of the signal d. If u is not None and d is None, then d is set to zero with the same length of the signal u. If u and d are not None, then they should have the same number of columns, otherwise an error is raised. If u and d are None, they are returned as none.

Parameters:

  • u (np.ndarray or None) – The input signal to be checked and regularized.

  • d (np.ndarray or None) – The disturbance signal to be checked and regularized.

Returns:

The regularized input and disturbance signals.

Return type:

tuple of np.ndarray (u, d)

abstract discrete_dynamics(x: ndarray, u: ndarray | None = None, d: ndarray | None = None)[source]

Discrete dynamics x_{k+1} = f(x_k,u_k,d_k)

Parameters:

  • u (np.ndarray) – input at time k

  • d (np.ndarray) – disturbance at time k

Returns:

state at time k+1

abstract simulate(x0: ndarray, u: ndarray | None = None, d: ndarray | None = None, steps: int = 10)[source]

Simulate the discrete time system for a number of steps. Input should be an array of size (steps, size_input) and disturbance should be an array of size (steps, disturbance_size) where steps is the number of steps to simulate.

Parameters:

  • x0 (np.ndarray) – initial state

  • u (np.ndarray) – input signal

  • d (np.ndarray) – disturbance signal

  • steps (int) – number of steps to simulate

Returns:

state trajectory

Return type:

models.nonlinear_system module

class NonlinearSystem(updfcn, states, inputs=None, disturbances=None, outfcn=None, dt=0.1)[source]

Bases: Model

static c2d(updfcn, states, inputs=None, disturbances=None, outfcn=None, dt=0.1, integrator='RK4', **kwargs)[source]

Create a discrete-time NonlinearSystem from a continuous-time model using numerical integration.

Parameters:

  • updfcn (casadi.MX,casadi.SX) – The update expression f(x, u, d) that defines the system dynamics.

  • states (casadi.MX,casadi.SX) – The system states.

  • inputs (casadi.MX,casadi.SX, optional) – The system inputs.

  • disturbances (casadi.MX,casadi.SX, optional) – The system disturbances.

  • outfcn (casadi.MX,casadi.SX, optional) – The output function g(x, u, d).

  • dt (float, optional) – The time step. Defaults to 0.1.

  • integrator (str, optional) – The integrator type. Defaults to ‘RK4’.

Returns:

The discrete-time system.

Return type:

NonlinearSystem

compute_lqr_controller(Q, R, x_ref: ndarray | None = None, u_ref: ndarray | None = None, d_ref: ndarray | None = None)[source]

Compute the infinite-horizon LQR controller for the given prediction model.

Parameters:

  • Q (np.ndarray) – The state cost matrix.

  • R (np.ndarray) – The input cost matrix.

  • x_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference state vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘x’ in the prediction model.

  • u_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference input vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘u’ in the prediction model.

  • d_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference disturbance vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘d’ in the prediction model.

Returns:

The LQR controller gain matrix, the Riccati solution, and the discrete-time state-space model.

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray

discrete_dynamics(x, u=None, d=None)[source]

Discrete dynamics

\[x_{k+1} = f(x_k,u_k,d_k)\]
Parameters:

  • x (np.ndarray) – The current state.

  • u (np.ndarray, optional) – The current input.

  • d (np.ndarray, optional) – The current disturbance.

Returns:

The next state.

Return type:

np.ndarray

property dt

discrete time step of the model

get_target_point(yref: ndarray, d: ndarray | None = None)[source]

Given a reference output valye y_ref we want to find the the eqilubrium pair (xref, uref) that satisfies the equilibrium conditions:

x_ref = f(x_ref, u_ref, d) y_ref = g(x_ref, u_ref, d)

Parameters:

  • yref (np.ndarray) – The reference output value.

  • d (np.ndarray, optional) – The disturbance signal. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘d’ in the prediction model.

Returns:

The equilibrium state x_ref and input u_ref.

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray

linearize(x_ref: ndarray | None = None, u_ref: ndarray | None = None, d_ref: ndarray | None = None)[source]

Linearize the NonlinearSystem around a target point with the form (xref, uref, dref).

x_{k+1} = A*(x_k - xref) + B*(u_k - uref) + Bd*(d_k - dref) y_k = C*(x_k - xref) + D*(u_k - uref) + Dd*(d_k - dref)

Parameters:

  • x_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference state vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘x’ in the prediction model.

  • u_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference input vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘u’ in the prediction model.

  • d_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference disturbance vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘d’ in the prediction model.

Returns:

The system matrices A, B, C, D, Bd, Dd.

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray

output(x, u=None, d=None)[source]

Output function

\[y_k = g(x_k,u_k,d_k)\]
Parameters:

  • x (np.ndarray) – The current state.

  • u (np.ndarray, optional) – The current input.

  • d (np.ndarray, optional) – The current disturbance.

Returns:

The output.

Return type:

np.ndarray

simulate(x0, u=None, d=None, steps=10)[source]

Simulate the discrete time system for a number of steps. Input should be an array of size (steps, size_input) and disturbance should be an array of size (steps, disturbance_size) where steps is the number of steps to simulate.

Parameters:

  • x0 (np.ndarray) – The initial state.

  • u (np.ndarray, optional) – The input signal.

  • d (np.ndarray, optional) – The disturbance signal.

  • steps (int) – The number of steps to simulate.

Returns:

The state trajectory and output trajectory.

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray

property size_disturbance

Number of disturbance inputs to the system.

property size_input

Number of inputs to the system.

property size_output

Number of outputs of the system.

property size_state

Module contents

class LinearSystem(A: ndarray, B: ndarray | None = None, C: ndarray | None = None, D: ndarray | None = None, Bd: ndarray | None = None, Cd: ndarray | None = None, dt: float = 1)[source]

Bases: Model

Simple base class to define a linear system in state-space form. The system is assumed to be discrete-time. You can use the class method c2d obtain a discerete system from continuous time matrices if required.

Model of the system

\[ \begin{align}\begin{aligned}x_{k+1} = A x_k + B u_k + Bd d_k\\y_k = C x_k + D u_k + Cd d_k\end{aligned}\end{align} \]
property A

State matrix

property B

Input matrix

property Bd
property C

Output matrix

property Cd
property D
static c2d(A_cont, B_cont, C_cont, D_cont, dt)[source]

Convert continuous-time state-space model to discrete-time.

Parameters:

  • A_cont (np.ndarray) – Continuous-time state matrix

  • B_cont (np.ndarray) – Continuous-time input matrix

  • C_cont (np.ndarray) – Continuous-time output matrix

  • D_cont (np.ndarray) – Continuous-time feedforward matrix

  • dt (float) – Sampling time

Returns:

Discrete-time state-space model

Return type:

LinearSystem

simulate(x0, u=None, d=None, steps=10)[source]

Simulate the discrete time system for a number of steps. Input should be an array of size (size_input,steps) and disturbance should be an array of size (disturbance_size,steps) where steps is the number of steps to simulate. Note that the function will attempt to reshape your array to the given form (size_input,steps). Hence the output will not be the length you expact if you have an array with typed the wrong dimensions.

Parameters:

  • x0 (np.ndarray) – Initial state vector

  • u (np.ndarray) – Input signal

  • d (np.ndarray) – Disturbance signal

  • steps (int) – Number of steps to simulate

Return x_trj:

State trajectory of shape (size_state, steps+1)

Rtype x_trj:

np.ndarray

Return y_trj:

Output trajectory of shape (size_output, steps)

Rtype y_trj:

np.ndarray

class NonlinearSystem(updfcn, states, inputs=None, disturbances=None, outfcn=None, dt=0.1)[source]

Bases: Model

static c2d(updfcn, states, inputs=None, disturbances=None, outfcn=None, dt=0.1, integrator='RK4', **kwargs)[source]

Create a discrete-time NonlinearSystem from a continuous-time model using numerical integration.

Parameters:

  • updfcn (casadi.MX,casadi.SX) – The update expression f(x, u, d) that defines the system dynamics.

  • states (casadi.MX,casadi.SX) – The system states.

  • inputs (casadi.MX,casadi.SX, optional) – The system inputs.

  • disturbances (casadi.MX,casadi.SX, optional) – The system disturbances.

  • outfcn (casadi.MX,casadi.SX, optional) – The output function g(x, u, d).

  • dt (float, optional) – The time step. Defaults to 0.1.

  • integrator (str, optional) – The integrator type. Defaults to ‘RK4’.

Returns:

The discrete-time system.

Return type:

NonlinearSystem

compute_lqr_controller(Q, R, x_ref: ndarray | None = None, u_ref: ndarray | None = None, d_ref: ndarray | None = None)[source]

Compute the infinite-horizon LQR controller for the given prediction model.

Parameters:

  • Q (np.ndarray) – The state cost matrix.

  • R (np.ndarray) – The input cost matrix.

  • x_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference state vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘x’ in the prediction model.

  • u_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference input vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘u’ in the prediction model.

  • d_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference disturbance vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘d’ in the prediction model.

Returns:

The LQR controller gain matrix, the Riccati solution, and the discrete-time state-space model.

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray

  • d (np.ndarray, optional) – The current disturbance.

Returns:

get_target_point(yref: ndarray, d: ndarray | None = None)[source]

Given a reference output valye y_ref we want to find the the eqilubrium pair (xref, uref) that satisfies the equilibrium conditions:

x_ref = f(x_ref, u_ref, d) y_ref = g(x_ref, u_ref, d)

Parameters:

  • yref (np.ndarray) – The reference output value.

  • d (np.ndarray, optional) – The disturbance signal. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘d’ in the prediction model.

Returns:

The equilibrium state x_ref and input u_ref.

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray

linearize(x_ref: ndarray | None = None, u_ref: ndarray | None = None, d_ref: ndarray | None = None)[source]

Linearize the NonlinearSystem around a target point with the form (xref, uref, dref).

x_{k+1} = A*(x_k - xref) + B*(u_k - uref) + Bd*(d_k - dref) y_k = C*(x_k - xref) + D*(u_k - uref) + Dd*(d_k - dref)

Parameters:

  • x_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference state vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘x’ in the prediction model.

  • u_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference input vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘u’ in the prediction model.

  • d_ref (np.ndarray, optional) – The reference disturbance vector. If not provided, set to a zero vector of the same dimension as ‘d’ in the prediction model.

Returns:

The system matrices A, B, C, D, Bd, Dd.

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray, np.ndarray

simulate(x0, u=None, d=None, steps=10)[source]

Simulate the discrete time system for a number of steps. Input should be an array of size (steps, size_input) and disturbance should be an array of size (steps, disturbance_size) where steps is the number of steps to simulate.

Parameters:

  • x0 (np.ndarray) – The initial state.

  • u (np.ndarray, optional) – The input signal.

  • d (np.ndarray, optional) – The disturbance signal.

  • steps (int) – The number of steps to simulate.

Returns:

The state trajectory and output trajectory.

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray
